original_data.question: A 22-year-old woman from a rural area who recently discovered she was pregnant is referred for a cardiology consultation due to cyanosis, dyspnea, and a cardiac murmur revealed at the initial prenatal visit. She is gravida 1, para 0 with an estimated gestational age of 19 weeks. She says that the murmur was found in her childhood, and the doctor at that time placed her under observation only. However, she has been lost to follow-up and has not had proper follow up in years. Currently, she complains of dizziness and occasional dyspnea on exertion which has gradually increased during her pregnancy. Prior to her pregnancy, she did not have any symptoms. The vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 125/60 mm Hg, heart rate 81/min, respiratory rate 13/min, and temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F). Her examination is significant for acrocyanosis and a fixed splitting of S2 and grade 3/6 midsystolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border. Which of the following physiological pregnancy changes is causing the change in this patient’s condition?

model_response:
The physiological changes of pregnancy that affect this patient’s condition are:

Increase in heart rate
Increase in cardiac output
Increase in blood volume
Decrease in systemic vascular resistance

This patient has a congenital heart defect, probably an atrial septal defect (ASD). The increase in cardiac output and the decrease in systemic vascular resistance during pregnancy will increase the shunt across the ASD, leading to worsening of the patient’s symptoms.

The increase in heart rate during pregnancy will also contribute to the murmur intensity. The increase in blood volume contributes to the increase in cardiac output.

The increase in body temperature during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in abdominal pressure due to the growing uterus will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in respiratory rate during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in renal blood flow during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in gastrointestinal activity during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in glomerular filtration rate during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in intravascular volume during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in hematocrit during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in progesterone levels during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) levels during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in intrapulmonary pressure during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in minute ventilation during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in oxygen consumption during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in renal blood flow during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in uterine blood flow during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in venous pressure during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in body weight during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in diaphragm elevation during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in subcostal angle during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in transverse diameter of the chest during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in the anteroposterior diameter of the chest during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in the size of the inferior vena cava during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in the size of the right ventricle during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in the size of the left atrium during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in the size of the right atrium during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in the size of the pulmonary artery during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in the size of the aorta during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in the size of the left ventricle during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in the size of the right ventricular outflow tract during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in the size of the vena cavae during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in the size of the aortic root during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in the size of the pulmonary artery during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

The increase in the size of the atrial septum during pregnancy will not affect the intensity of the murmur.

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
A non-urbanized geographic area. "Rural" encompasses densely settled small towns with a residential population of less than 2,500 people, more sparsely populated areas, and remote areas.
See for the first time; identify.
Observed to be or have been pregnant.
The study of the heart, its physiology, and its functions.
A conference between two or more people to consider a particular question; the act of deliberating together; confering with another researcher, physician, or expert about an issue or a case.
A bluish or purplish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes due to an increase in the amount of deoxygenated hemoglobin in the blood or a structural defect in the hemoglobin molecule.
Difficult or labored breathing.

Heart sounds caused by vibrations resulting from the flow of blood through the heart. Heart murmurs can be examined by HEART AUSCULTATION, and analyzed by their intensity (6 grades), duration, timing (systolic, diastolic, or continuous), location, transmission, and quality (musical, vibratory, blowing, etc).
The number of offspring a female has borne. It is contrasted with GRAVIDITY, which refers to the number of pregnancies, regardless of outcome.

The age of the conceptus, beginning from the time of FERTILIZATION. In clinical obstetrics, the gestational age is often estimated from the onset of the last MENSTRUATION which is about 2 weeks before OVULATION and fertilization. It is also estimated to begin from fertilization, estrus, coitus, or artificial insemination.
Any period of seven consecutive days.

Heart sounds caused by vibrations resulting from the flow of blood through the heart. Heart murmurs can be examined by HEART AUSCULTATION, and analyzed by their intensity (6 grades), duration, timing (systolic, diastolic, or continuous), location, transmission, and quality (musical, vibratory, blowing, etc).
A time period that begins at the beginning of the human embryonic stage and continues until the end of adolescence.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
The dimension of the physical universe which, at a given place, orders the sequence of events. (McGraw-Hill Dictionary of Scientific and Technical Terms, 6th ed)

The act of regarding attentively and studying facts and occurrences, gathering data through analyzing, measuring, and drawing conclusions, with the purpose of applying the observed information to theoretical assumptions. Observation as a scientific method in the acquisition of knowledge began in classical antiquity; in modern science and medicine its greatest application is facilitated by modern technology. Observation is one of the components of the research process.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
A symptom or problem for which a patient seeks medical attention.
An imprecise term which may refer to a sense of spatial disorientation, motion of the environment, or lightheadedness.
Not occurring regularly or at short intervals.
Physical or mental energy; hard work.
The status during which female mammals carry their developing young (EMBRYOS or FETUSES) in utero before birth, beginning from FERTILIZATION to BIRTH.
The status during which female mammals carry their developing young (EMBRYOS or FETUSES) in utero before birth, beginning from FERTILIZATION to BIRTH.
Actions performed to measure temperature, pulse, respirations, and blood pressure
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
The number of times the HEART VENTRICLES contract per unit of time, usually per minute.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Persistent, symmetric, and painless blue discoloration of the extremities. It is the result of vasospasm in response to cold. The affected areas are cold and sweaty.
An auscultated finding in which the semilunar valve closure sounds do not vary with respiration. (ACC-AHA)
A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.
Period of contraction of the HEART, especially of the HEART VENTRICLES.

Heart sounds caused by vibrations resulting from the flow of blood through the heart. Heart murmurs can be examined by HEART AUSCULTATION, and analyzed by their intensity (6 grades), duration, timing (systolic, diastolic, or continuous), location, transmission, and quality (musical, vibratory, blowing, etc).
A condition in which a person partially loses the ability to hear sounds in one or both ears.
Pertaining to functions of the body.
The status during which female mammals carry their developing young (EMBRYOS or FETUSES) in utero before birth, beginning from FERTILIZATION to BIRTH.
The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.
A description of the physiological status of a patient.
